title: Cobolli's Epic Tie-Break Victory Propels Italy to Davis Cup Final
summary: In a thrilling Davis Cup semifinal match, Italian tennis player Flavio Cobolli secured a dramatic victory over Belgium's Zizou Bergs by winning a 32-point tie-break, after saving seven match points. The intense contest lasted over three hours and ended with Cobolli prevailing 6-3, 6-7 (5-7), 7-6 (17-15), sparking wild celebrations among the home crowd in Bologna. Cobolli described the win as one of the best days of his life, emphasizing the significance of playing for his nation, team, and family. This victory places Italy in the final against Spain or Germany, where they aim to become the first country in over 50 years to win three consecutive Davis Cup titles. Italy's captain, Filippo Volandri, praised Cobolli's immense heart and effort, noting that tactics played a minor role compared to determination. Despite missing top players like Jannik Sinner and Lorenzo Musetti, Italy's team, supported by a sell-out crowd of 10,000 fans, showed resilience, with teammate Matteo Berrettini also contributing an earlier win. This achievement marks Italy as the first nation since Australia in 2001 to reach three straight Davis Cup finals, highlighting their growing dominance in team tennis.

Italy has been successful recently, winning the last two editions, and a third win would place them in rare company, as no nation has achieved this since the 1970s. Flavio Cobolli, ranked 22nd globally, is part of a new generation of Italian players stepping up in the absence of stars like Jannik Sinner. Tie-breaks were introduced to tennis in the 1970s to resolve tied sets, and long tie-breaks, like the 32-point one here, are memorable for their intensity and drama. The event in Bologna drew a full crowd, reflecting the passion for tennis in Italy and the importance of home support in team competitions.
